title: Server Name disclosure
vulnerability_information:
Hi,
I found a Server Name disclosure (Cowboy) in the your web server's HTTP response!
This information might help an attacker gain a greater understanding of the systems in use and potentially develop further attacks targeted at the  Server!

Request with Burp:

GET / HTTP/1.1
Host: qa.qulture.rocks
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:52.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/52.0 Cyberfox/52.9.1
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1
Cookie: _qulture_session_cross_%3D--ab8c521463c8bb731d9cc1f0aa07aea0c2fa7e44; XSRF-TOKEN=3%2BLluwPUgkrqKVdQx%2FtkHs8MmCs9rqLa1dSQVJZryL0VnGvAoxy%2F7lUJX4%2Bs1hOpSYfPqGFfTWntdq2861fafg%3D%3D; intercom-id-mu4wbc1e=2d06af07-6f68-42f4-8bb8-5ab780127c2c; intercom-session-mu4wbc1e=; _ALWM=0bbd61f9-f463-9148-4424-a1f540044d00; _ga=GA1.2.1583835020.1584769651; _gid=GA1.2.2114290316.1584769651; px_anonymousId=dec8711d-019c-2abc-fadc-4b9f763f0739; ajs_anonymous_id=%22dec8711d-019c-2abc-fadc-4b9f763f0739%22; _gaexp=GAX1.2.jMrjHA3SRUmK5ENIgvRV3Q.18388.0; _hjid=544dfe32-1848-46c6-97c9-98282c16eac0; __trf.src=encoded_eyJmaXJzdF9zZXNzaW9uIjp7InZhbHVlIjoiKG5vbmUpIiwiZXh0cmFfcGFyYW1zIjp7fX0sImN1cnJlbnRfc2Vzc2lvbiI6eyJ2YWx1ZSI6Iihub25lKSIsImV4dHJhX3BhcmFtcyI6e319LCJjcmVhdGVkX2F0IjoxNTg0NzY5NjU1NDY0fQ==; rdtrk=%7B%22id%22%3A%225f538339-8f94-4c6d-8283-c2c4399293f4%22%7D; mp_82773fb011941ca9badafdc4e9aec163_mixpanel=%7B%22distinct_id%22%3A%20%22170fba14d2449d-0725e5b740d0b3-483d385e-100200-170fba14d2627d%22%2C%22%24device_id%22%3A%20%22170fba14d2449d-0725e5b740d0b3-483d385e-100200-170fba14d2627d%22%2C%22%24initial_referrer%22%3A%20%22%24direct%22%2C%22%24initial_referring_domain%22%3A%20%22%24direct%22%7D
Connection: close

## Impact

An attacker might use the disclosed information to harvest specific security vulnerabilities for the Server identified.

Hi,
I found a Server Name disclosure (Cowboy) in the your web server's HTTP response!
This information might help an attacker gain a greater understanding of the systems in use and potentially develop further attacks targeted at the Server!

Request with Burp:

GET / HTTP/1.1
Host: qa.qulture.rocks
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:52.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/52.0 Cyberfox/52.9.1
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,/;q=0.8

Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1
Cookie: _qulture_session_cross_%3D--ab8c521463c8bb731d9cc1f0aa07aea0c2fa7e44; XSRF-TOKEN=3%2BLluwPUgkrqKVdQx%2FtkHs8MmCs9rqLa1dSQVJZryL0VnGvAoxy%2F7lUJX4%2Bs1hOpSYfPqGFfTWntdq2861fafg%3D%3D; intercom-id-mu4wbc1e=2d06af07-6f68-42f4-8bb8-5ab780127c2c; intercom-session-mu4wbc1e=; _ALWM=0bbd61f9-f463-9148-4424-a1f540044d00; _ga=GA1.2.1583835020.1584769651; _gid=GA1.2.2114290316.1584769651; px_anonymousId=dec8711d-019c-2abc-fadc-4b9f763f0739; ajs_anonymous_id=%22dec8711d-019c-2abc-fadc-4b9f763f0739%22; _gaexp=GAX1.2.jMrjHA3SRUmK5ENIgvRV3Q.18388.0; _hjid=544dfe32-1848-46c6-97c9-98282c16eac0; __trf.src=encoded_eyJmaXJzdF9zZXNzaW9uIjp7InZhbHVlIjoiKG5vbmUpIiwiZXh0cmFfcGFyYW1zIjp7fX0sImN1cnJlbnRfc2Vzc2lvbiI6eyJ2YWx1ZSI6Iihub25lKSIsImV4dHJhX3BhcmFtcyI6e319LCJjcmVhdGVkX2F0IjoxNTg0NzY5NjU1NDY0fQ==; rdtrk=%7B%22id%22%3A%225f538339-8f94-4c6d-8283-c2c4399293f4%22%7D; mp_82773fb011941ca9badafdc4e9aec163_mixpanel=%7B%22distinct_id%22%3A%20%22170fba14d2449d-0725e5b740d0b3-483d385e-100200-170fba14d2627d%22%2C%22%24device_id%22%3A%20%22170fba14d2449d-0725e5b740d0b3-483d385e-100200-170fba14d2627d%22%2C%22%24initial_referrer%22%3A%20%22%24direct%22%2C%22%24initial_referring_domain%22%3A%20%22%24direct%22%7D
Connection: close

Impact

An attacker might use the disclosed information to harvest specific security vulnerabilities for the Server identified.

activities.message:
Hi @julfikar @3x3s thank you for your reports!

We are investigating this issue and will get back to you shortly
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @julfikar @3x3s thank you for your reports!

We are investigating this issue and will get back to you shortly

activities.message:
Hi @julfikar 

I've been chatting with Heroku support about this issue and this is their response

> This has been in place for a long time. To my understanding, there is no way to disable this output. This is also visible via a simple curl command (using the options -Ivk). I have never heard of anyone taking advantage of knowing the server version to attack an app server. That said, I will ask our Runtime team if they know of anything that could disable this. If they get back to me, I will let you know. Otherwise, assume that there is no way to disable this. Feel free to follow up with any other questions you might have that I can answer for you.

> It seems like there is a way to overwrite the content of Via by providing your own, but I believe this may simply amend what you add.

> I just had another really good point brought to my attention. 1.1 does not seem to be indicating the version of vegur but instead the HTTP version being used to process the request. I'm hoping that this will appease your concerns around this.

Since there isn't much we can do, and Heroku seems sure this is not a security issue, I'm closing this as Informative

Thank you again for your report
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @julfikar

I've been chatting with Heroku support about this issue and this is their response

This has been in place for a long time. To my understanding, there is no way to disable this output. This is also visible via a simple curl command (using the options -Ivk). I have never heard of anyone taking advantage of knowing the server version to attack an app server. That said, I will ask our Runtime team if they know of anything that could disable this. If they get back to me, I will let you know. Otherwise, assume that there is no way to disable this. Feel free to follow up with any other questions you might have that I can answer for you.

It seems like there is a way to overwrite the content of Via by providing your own, but I believe this may simply amend what you add.

I just had another really good point brought to my attention. 1.1 does not seem to be indicating the version of vegur but instead the HTTP version being used to process the request. I'm hoping that this will appease your concerns around this.

Since there isn't much we can do, and Heroku seems sure this is not a security issue, I'm closing this as Informative

Thank you again for your report
